cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Pandemonium
planes.philosophicalEssence: Overwhelming chaos manifested as howling wind through endless dark tunnels. The plane of last straws, where incessant howling brings everyone to the edge of lashing out in frustration, breaking down in despair, or dissolving into incoherence.
planes.emotionalInfluence: The incessant winds force inhabitants and visitors toward frustration, despair, and incoherence. Simply existing on the plane is exhausting; trying to accomplish even a basic conversation is aggravating.

physicalProperties.shape: A great mass of rock riddled with tunnels carved by howling winds
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Breathable but filled with howling winds that extinguish nonmagical open flames and make conversation possible only by yelling to a maximum distance of 10 feet.

temperature.description: Cold plane with no natural light. Blowing snow in some layers.

physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Constant howling winds of varying intensity through tunnel systems. Blowing snow in Pandesmos.

layers.name: Pandesmos
layers.description: Howling winds, dark streams bound for the River Styx, and blowing snow pour through vast, desolate caverns.

layerSpecificHazards.name: Howling Winds
layerSpecificHazards.description: Howling winds pour through vast, desolate caverns along with blowing snow.

layerSpecificHazards.name: Dark Streams
layerSpecificHazards.description: Dark streams bound for the River Styx flow through the caverns.

layers.environmentalDescription: Vast, desolate caverns with howling winds, dark streams, and blowing snow.

layers.name: Cocytus
layers.description: Winds blowing through narrower tunnels create a stronger force and louder wails, making this the so-called 'Layer of Lamentation.'

notableLocations.name: Howler's Crag
notableLocations.description: A jagged spike rumored to have a unique magical property: anything yelled from the top of the crag is said to find the ears of its intended recipient—carried on a shrieking, frigid wind—no matter where in the multiverse that person might be.

layerSpecificHazards.name: Intensified Winds
layerSpecificHazards.description: Winds blowing through narrower tunnels create a stronger force and louder wails than Pandesmos.

layers.environmentalDescription: Narrower tunnels with stronger, louder winds that create wailing sounds, earning it the name 'Layer of Lamentation.'

layers.name: Phlegethon
layers.description: Tunnel walls absorb light while water creates intricate rock formations.

layerSpecificHazards.name: Light-Absorbing Walls
layerSpecificHazards.description: Tunnel walls absorb light, making illumination even more difficult than in the upper layers.

lightLevel.colorDescription: No visible light; tunnel walls absorb illumination

layers.environmentalDescription: Tunnels whose walls absorb light, creating an even deeper darkness. Water flowing through the tunnels creates intricate rock formations.

layers.name: Agathion
layers.description: Sealed-off tunnels are largely inaccessible from elsewhere, making them ideal as vaults for ancient secrets.
layers.environmentalDescription: Sealed-off tunnels largely inaccessible from elsewhere. Used as vaults for ancient secrets.

timeFlow.description: Time flows normally on Pandemonium, though the lack of natural light and the constant howling winds make tracking time difficult.

hazards.name: Howling Winds of Pandemonium
hazards.description: Pandemonium is riddled with tunnels carved by howling winds. The winds are constant and overwhelming, extinguishing nonmagical open flames such as torches and campfires, and making conversation possible only by yelling to a maximum distance of 10 feet.

dayNightCycle.description: No natural light exists on Pandemonium.

effectOnConversation.reason: The howling winds make conversation possible only by yelling, and even then only to a maximum distance of 10 feet.

windForce.description: Howling winds pour through vast tunnels, varying in intensity across layers. In Cocytus, narrower tunnels create even stronger force.

hazards.sourceReference: Chapter 6: Cosmology - Pandemonium; Environmental Effects in Chapter 3

hazards.name: No Natural Light
hazards.description: Pandemonium is dark with no natural light. Wind quickly extinguishes nonmagical open flames such as torches and campfires.

hazards.name: Cold Environment
hazards.description: Pandemonium is cold. Blowing snow in Pandesmos and frigid winds throughout the plane.

hazards.name: Wind-Driven Madness
hazards.description: The incessant howling of the winds brings everyone on the plane, sooner or later, to the edge of lashing out in frustration, breaking down in despair, or dissolving into incoherence—and then some event, force, or creature on the plane pushes them over that edge. See Environmental Effects in chapter 3 for more information about the winds of Pandemonium.
hazards.sourceReference: Chapter 6: Cosmology - Pandemonium; Environmental Effects in Chapter 3

hazards.name: Phlegethon Light Absorption
hazards.description: In Phlegethon, the third layer, tunnel walls absorb light, making illumination exceptionally difficult.

environmentalEffects.name: Winds of Pandemonium
environmentalEffects.description: The howling winds of Pandemonium extinguish nonmagical open flames and limit conversation to yelling at a maximum distance of 10 feet. The winds also drive inhabitants toward frustration, despair, or incoherence. Full mechanical effects are described in Environmental Effects in chapter 3.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: Nonmagical open flames (torches, campfires) are extinguished. Conversation is possible only by yelling, maximum distance 10 feet. Extended exposure drives creatures toward madness. Simply existing on the plane is exhausting.
environmentalEffects.emotionalEffect: The incessant howling brings everyone on the plane to the edge of lashing out in frustration, breaking down in despair, or dissolving into incoherence.
environmentalEffects.sourceReference: Chapter 6: Cosmology - Pandemonium; Environmental Effects in Chapter 3

portals.destination: The Plain of Infinite Portals (Layer 1 of the Abyss)

requirement.description: Portals from the first layer of the Abyss lead to Pandemonium among other destinations.
The gate-town of Bedlam in the Outlands contains a portal leading to Pandemonium.

planarConnections.name: River Styx
planarConnections.description: The River Styx churns through the top layers of Pandemonium. Tributaries of the Styx snake through lower layers. Sinister ferries float on the waters of the Styx, crewed by pilots skilled in negotiating the unpredictable currents.
hazards: Ill effects of the Styx as described in chapter 3
navigableBy: Sinister ferries crewed by Fiends or souls of the dead

planarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
planarConnections.description: The roots of Yggdrasil, the World Tree, stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Planar travelers can climb among the roots and branches to travel from plane to plane.
hazards: Ever-changing paths as the tree continues its eternal growth

primaryCreatureTypes: Creatures banished to the plane with no hope of escape

specialRules.name: Wind Extinguishes Nonmagical Flames
specialRules.description: The howling winds of Pandemonium quickly extinguish nonmagical open flames such as torches and campfires.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: All nonmagical open flames (torches, campfires, etc.) are automatically extinguished by the wind. Only magical light sources or enclosed lanterns can provide illumination.

specialRules.name: Limited Conversation Distance
specialRules.description: The howling winds make conversation possible only by yelling, and even then only to a maximum distance of 10 feet.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Verbal communication is limited to yelling. Maximum conversation distance is 10 feet. This may affect spells with verbal components or abilities that require a creature to hear the caster at greater distances.

specialRules.name: Howler's Crag Magical Property
specialRules.description: A jagged spike in Cocytus called Howler's Crag is rumored to have a unique magical property: anything yelled from the top of the crag is said to find the ears of its intended recipient—carried on a shrieking, frigid wind—no matter where in the multiverse that person might be.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Messages yelled from the top of Howler's Crag reach the intended recipient anywhere in the multiverse, carried on a shrieking, frigid wind.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on Pandemonium, a Celestial makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, it must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: The d4 penalty is cumulative with each failed save. Each failed Long Rest save adds another 1d4 subtracted from all D20 Tests.

onSuccess.description: No additional dissonance penalty accrued from this rest.

autoSuccessConditions: Creature is on a plane that is not opposed to its nature
recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature ends all cumulative effects

planarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit Pandemonium (a Lower Plane) experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest, a Celestial makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, it must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

adventureThemes: Exploring what happens to characters on their worst day when everything goes wrong
Conveying frustration without transferring it to the players
Banishment and imprisonment with no hope of escape

crossReferences.description: Environmental Effects in Chapter 3 for more information about the winds of Pandemonium

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Styx
globalPlanarConnections.description: The River Styx bubbles with grease, foul flotsam, and the putrid remains of battles along its banks. It churns through the top layers of Acheron, the Nine Hells, Gehenna, Hades, Carceri, the Abyss, and Pandemonium. Tributaries snake through lower layers of these planes.
hazards: Ill effects of the Styx described in chapter 3
navigableBy: Sinister ferries crewed by Fiend pilots or souls of the dead

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is a cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Most of its trunk rises through Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.
hazards: Ever-changing paths as the tree continues its eternal growth

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: An extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down.
hazards: Guarded by devas, sphinxes, yugoloths, and other powerful monsters
navigableBy: Any creature that finds a door

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Portals can be doorways, locations, or vortices.
requirements: Meeting the portal's requirements (command, key item, random timing, situation, or time-based)
risks: Portals may not be open at all times

planarTravelMethods.name: Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to different planes of existence.
risks: Varying degrees of precision in destination

planarTravelMethods.name: River Styx
planarTravelMethods.description: Sinister ferries float on the waters of the Styx, crewed by pilots skilled in negotiating the unpredictable currents and eddies of the river. For a price, these pilots carry passengers from plane to plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
planarTravelMethods.description: Planar travelers can climb among the roots and branches of Yggdrasil to travel from plane to plane or world to world.

planarTravelMethods.name: Infinite Staircase
planarTravelMethods.description: An extradimensional staircase connecting the planes via nondescript doors found in dusty, half-forgotten places.
requirements: Finding a door to the staircase
risks: Chaotic jumble of stairs with varying gravitational orientation

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to the creature's nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds another 1d4 subtracted from all D20 Tests.

onSuccess.description: No additional dissonance penalty is accrued from this Long Rest.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature ends all cumulative effects

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
